title: The Roaring 20's (TV series)
text:
The Roaring 20s is an American <a href="Dramatic%20programming">drama</a> <a href="television%20series">television series</a> starring <a href="Rex%20Reason">Rex Reason</a>, <a href="Donald%20May">Donald May</a> and <a href="Dorothy%20Provine">Dorothy Provine</a> that was broadcast by the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">American Broadcasting Company</a> (ABC) from October 15, 1960, until January 20, 1962.
Synopsis.
Each episode of the series is an hour long. It concerns newspaper reporters reporting crime and gangsters for the fictitious newspaper "The New York Record" during the 1920s, such as Scott Norris (<a href="Rex%20Reason">Rex Reason</a>), Pat Garrison (<a href="Donald%20May">Donald May</a>), Duke Williams (<a href="John%20Dehner">John Dehner</a>), and copy-boy Chris Higby (<a href="Gary%20Vinson">Gary Vinson</a>). <a href="Mike%20Road">Mike Road</a> played police Lieutenant Joe Switoski. <a href="Dorothy%20Provine">Dorothy Provine</a> features as Pinky Pinkham, the singer at the Charleston Club, in all 45 episodes. Other major actors were <a href="James%20Flavin">James Flavin</a> as Robert Howard and Louise Glenn as Gladys, who appear in 33 and 30 episodes, respectively.
Reception.
During its first year, "The Roaring 20's" had competition from the "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" (<a href="CBS">CBS</a>) and "<a href="Bonanza">Bonanza</a>" (<a href="NBC">NBC</a>). For the 1961-1962 season, however, "Bonanza" was shifted to Sunday, and the <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series, "<a href="Tales%20of%20Wells%20Fargo">Tales of Wells Fargo</a>," shifted into the time slot opposite "The Roaring 20's".
Soundtrack album.
In 1960 <a href="Warner%20Bros.%20Records">Warner Bros. Records</a> issued the soundtrack album "The Roaring 20's" to accompany the series (The full album title was: "Music from The Roaring 20's Warner Bros. New Hit Television Show, Songs by Dorothy Provine and the Music of Pinky and Her Playboys"). Musical direction was by <a href="Alexander%20Courage">Sandy Courage</a>.
